Real-Time Response and its Analytics System for School Classrooms

CLIENT EdAI Technologies AB

LOCATION Stockholm

DURATION 4 weeks - (It was spread out over 2 months as we had to wait for some steps such as recruiting participants)

CONTRIBUTION Individual Contributor with feedback from devs and stakeholders

üßë‚Äçüîß The Problem

EdAI needed to build a chat and response system for students and its real-time analytics counterpart for teachers in 2 months

I was hired as the first designer to develop the designs in an iterative manner that can be used by the developers in 2 months. When I arrived, there were 2 developers, CEO, and CTO. The startup had just assembled a team and it was very small. There was a minimal prototype that the company had already developed with a basic response system for students and a real-time analytics interface for teachers for a competition at Antler.

Schools have been using several tools to manage administrative work. EdAider wanted to bridge the gap with a single tool and robust analytics. EdAider needed designs that would cater to children in a playful way as well as to the teachers in a professional way.

ü•Ö Goals


To provide students with a response system to register their status directly to teachers.
Goal 1


To provide teachers with real-time response analytics to take fast and accurate decisions in the classroom.
Goal 2

ü§† Outcomes


Tyres√∂ school was onboard for testing the product throughout the summer. There have been a few hiccups due to COVID and the testing did not go as planned.
Outcome 1


Later on, with further iterated product design, EdAIder successfully partnered with Stockholm Stad. Offered to buy the product for 3 schools starting in August 2020.
Outcome 2

üî¨ Prior Research and Information

EdAider had been working with a team of researchers at Stockholm University in the learning analytics team. The CEO is a professor at Stockholm University. Hence, I did not conduct any big user study at this point. Instead, I decided to use the University research data and rely on a Facebook feedback group that we had set up for teachers to interact with.

I asked the professor to compile the results from the researchers which I could use from initial wireframes. The prior research led us to these conclusions about the response systems.

  • Students need different categories of responses namely knowledge, motivation, engagement and health to register what they feel during a class
  • Each category can have several responses
  • It would be better to have all the responses visible at once for student‚Äôs ease
  • A chat system to ask general questions to the teacher

üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶ People using our product

Based on the information compiled thorugh existing research, I was able to map out our users. While the customers are Swedish schools, the product is used by K-12 students and teachers.

üó∫Ô∏è Customer Journey Map

While students and teachers are our users, our customers are the Swedish schools that would eventually buy the premium version of EdAider. in the acquisition process, teachers play an important role since they are involved and judge the demonstration and then collectively decide whether or not to use the system along with the management.

üßê Competitor Analysis

While we always look for competitors as companies, often the major competitor is something more simple and hidden. An example is that water is the major competitor of Cola. Yes, Cola needed to overcome water's thirst-quenching ability to make it successful.

This is why for EdAider, the major competitor in the old practices in schools itself. Teachers can ask students whether they understood things, are motivated or focused, and get responses. A big part of education is still reliant on these manual methods and could create resistance to automated solutions. Often, there is also a psychological effect at play that a machine program cannot be better than a human in judgments related to education (from Thinking Fast and Slow - Daniel Kahneman). It could lead to resisting new products.

üë®‚Äçüéì User flowchart

EdAider plans for a lot of features ranging from scheduling, response system, assessments to analytics. In this project, I focused on the response system.

‚ú® Initial Iteration

Based on the conclusions, I designed lo-fidelity frames for the students

  • About one half of the screen was for chat and the other half for responses
  • Four categories with three varying levels of responses
  • Response system was made to be visible at all times so the students can quickly register their responses

I did a quick user test with four students from my past University. I could not get school students quickly hence, I tried to make a replacement.

Unanimous feedback was to use emojis to make the responses fun and engaging

Design decisions: What and why

  • Emojis for engaging experience based on the user testing feedback
  • It allowed for more screen space for the chat as we wanted students to use the chat as much as possible
  • All the categories and their respective responses were taken from the research results of SU researchers
  • Emoji were combined with text because emojis can be a bit ambiguous at times and younger kids may not know the meaning of all emojis. The text makes it clearer
  • We added more responses which were highlighted by teachers via a Facebook feedback group. They outlined the need for having help, raising hands, and temperature. Help is used when students needed help with a specific query. Raise hands is used for any general query by the teacher. Or in cases where the teacher asks questions and lets students raise hands and then choose one among them. Health category was removed for the moment as it was deemed "not very useful" by teachers
  • Tabs were removed as the quiz and exam were decided to be pushed by the teacher directly during the class and students would receive it on their screen in real-time. But they would be able to view results when the lecture ends

Teacher Interface

Design decisions: What and why

  • Teachers wanted to view chat from the whole class thread, individual students and attendance as well
  • Teachers are able to record their lecture
  • Display bar charts for the response system which would be updated as soon as a response is registered

Iteration after feedback from teachers via a Facebook group

Design decisions: What and why

  • Ability to hide/show the chat so the teachers can focus on only the response analytics
  • Responses from Help Needed, Raising Hands and distracted on other tabs was important to teachers hence we put them at the top
  • Display charts for the response system which would be updated as soon as a response is registered
  • We decided to put the "recording lecture" at the bottom as some teachers would use and some were uncomfortable with using video recording. We decided to make it less important and place it in the bottom bar

üß™ Workshop with teachers

Before the week of pilot launch, we organized a workshop with teachers at Tyres√∂ school, Stockholm in Feb, 2020. The purpose was to demonstrate how to use EdAider to teachers and get feedback on the working system before the teachers started using it in their class.

Workshop Insights

Five teachers were positive by using the system

There was concern about students playing with the response system in unintended ways to distract teachers. A solution was suggested that we could perhaps limit the visibility of the responses all at once.

Teachers expressed the idea to disable/enable the chat, add custom responses and assessments such as quizzes, exams, evaluations

Teachers have laptops with varying resolutions. Some visualizations went below the screen

Two teachers expressed concerns about the privacy of using video recording

Teachers thought that the bar chart visualization could be simplified

‚ú® Further Iteration

While the school started using our product, COVID hit during the March in Stockholm and the teachers needed to prepare for distance learning. EdAider had to pivot into supporting classroom as well as distance learning. Some of the key decisions at this point were:

  • Supporting Livestream via Zoom integration
  • Online assessments such as quizzes, exams, exit tickets, and lesson evaluations
  • Teacher interface would still largely remain the same with iterations based on the feedback from the workshop

ü¶† It was going just well! But not so fast.

Remember, at the start, the team decided to focus on only web and tablet versions. But due to COVID, during the workshop which we did before, the teachers said that mobile design for students is quite a necessity.

The reason for this sudden request was that many students do not have laptops/tablets at home or if the family might be using one such device for all. It creates a hindrance to such students.

Some key insights that we got from the workshop for mobile design:

Teacher interface mobile design was not given much importance by teachers as they have access to laptops. Using mobile in hand while delivering lecture was not appropriate in a classroom setting.

The team also decided to support the mobile web during this time. Because it is a small team and there were limited resources and not feasible to hire a mobile app developer. For this reason, the reuglar native elements of mobile apps is not present in the mobile web design.

The focus needs to be on the content. The responses may be put in the background.

If possible, we keep all the categories of responses in some way. I decided to keep a few responses at the bottom which were used the most during the pilot. Upon expansion, the full range of responses is visible.

Even if it is mobile design, the features should not be downgraded.

Mobile Wireframes
  • While most of the design remains same, native android makes the navigation simpler through bottom nav bar
  • The top bar has icons for assessing "Livestream" and "Chat" and the lecture name in the middle
  • This part was not planned in the actual project. I am doing it in spare time. Hence, there is more to come.

üü¢ Click Prototype

Play through the prototype for a scenario where a student asks for help from the teacher. You can follow the blue attention boxes highlighting where to click when needed.

üéØ Final Outcomes


Tyres√∂ commune school offered continued usage of EdAider to help with feedback and usability workshops down the line
Outcome 1


It earned us membership at Swedish EdTech Industry and a grant from Vinnova to keep building for distance learning features
Outcome 2


The new designs led to a deal with Stockholm Stad to use premium version of EdAider at 3 schools in Autumn 2020
Outcome 3

üïµÔ∏è Reflections

COVID crisis allowed us to explore distance learning and forced us to make a platform that could work for them with certain changes

Juggling between lecture delivery and viewing real-time analytics. The teacher interface visualizations needs to be even more discrete

Teachers expressed the idea to disable/enable the chat, add custom responses and assessments such as quizzes, exams, evaluations

Students did not use the response system as expected. Due to GDPR issues, initial test run have been anonymous. Students did abuse the teachers. It was one of the reasons to ask for disabling/enabling chat feature

Two teachers expressed concerns about privacy of using video recording. We had to look for integrations with services like Zoom or Google doc to implement the design faster instead of reinventing the wheel
